Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Political Science: Demographics and Voter Participation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines the individual and structural factors that underlie a person's decision to vote. Prior research has made it clear that demographics affect how likely a person is to vote, and that increasing the costs associated with voting makes a person less likely to vote. The project constructs a new theory of voter turnout that merges these two findings, arguing that demographics determine political resources (including political knowledge and civic skills), which in turn determine whether a person is able to overcome the voting costs placed on him or her.

The project's intellectual merit is associated with its advances in theory and empirical research on voting. The project develops statistical models that test the interaction between demographics and voting costs to observe how voting costs differentially affect people based on their demographic characteristics. These models will account for demographics, the voting costs voters face, community characteristics, and the campaign environment. The project will provide insight into the costs that voters face and identify which types of voters are overburdened with voting costs and how turnout among these groups can be made more representative. The research examines voting costs that have received little attention in prior research, and incorporates several voting costs in the same model to discover precisely which costs are posing the greatest threat to turnout.

Studying voter turnout is of great importance because the people who vote tend to have more influence in matters of policy and government than those who do not vote. Voters have been shown to have different policy concerns than non-voters. If certain people routinely abstain from voting because the costs are too high, they may not be adequately represented in local, state, and federal government. This could leave segments of the population under-represented.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the differences among demographic groups in their ability to overcome institutional barriers to voter turnout in elections in the United States. The potential barriers we investigated include voter registration, requirements to show identification before voting, distance to polling place, and ballot length.

We found that certain demographic groups were largely unaffected by increases in these voting costs, while other turnout among other groups changed significantly. We found that people with traditionally higher levels of political resources—meaning those with higher education levels, higher incomes, and white-collar or full-time occupations, and those who are male or white—are less likely to vote when the act of voting is time-intensive, such as when the voter registration deadline is early or when there are many offices and ballot measures being voted on. In contrast, people with traditionally lower levels of political resources—those who have lower education levels or lower incomes, and those who are racial minorities—are less likely to vote when they are required to spend money in order to vote, such as being required to show identification before being able to vote.

Our project made several unique contributions to the understanding of voter turnout, namely by looking at voting costs that previously had not been studied in-depth and by building a turnout model that accounted for the demographic, cost, community, and campaign factors that influence voter turnout. We identified which specific institutional barriers were causing the greatest decreases in voter turnout and which demographic groups were most disadvantaged by increases in voting costs.

Voting is one of the most common and fundamental acts that citizens perform in democratic societies and elections serve as an important way for citizens to express what they want from their government, but many people do not vote at all. This project showed that for some people, voting is simply too difficult or costly. We hope that the results of this research will help election officials know how to increase voter turnout in elections.
